speechtext:
Mr. Speaker, we are all most grateful for the positive yes response to yesterday's referendum question in South Africa.
The majority yes response encourages people worldwide to continue to believe in the generous and just nature of humanity which so often is buried in the negative.
Yesterday's white South Africans voted overwhelmingly to support the end of apartheid. Seventy per cent of South Africa's 3 million white minority have given Mr. de Klerk the mandate to proceed with the CODESA reforms on behalf of all South Africans including 30 million black South Africans.
We look forward to a rapid negotiation of a new constitution enfranchising all citizens. We look forward to a speedy implementation of an interim government which will include blacks for the first time.
Most of all, we look forward to the achievement of these goals which will bring South Africa back as a full participant in the community of nations, sanctions lifted and freedom and prosperity for all, as the new goals for an international community.

Mr. Speaker, once again the province of champions does it. I ask this House to congratulate three new champions.
The ladies Canada West Ringette team from Alberta won the world's ringette championship in Helsinki, Finland.
During the same week, the Wetaskiwin Relics won the COHA international hockey tournament in Las Vegas for the second time, having previously won the world cup division in San Diego.
Of course, the whole nation watched the University of Alberta Golden Bears as they captured their eighth Canadian intercollegiate athletic union hockey championship in Toronto on Sunday.
The Golden Bears exemplify the winning tradition of the University of Alberta and all three teams exemplify the true ideals of excellence. As the Golden Bears say: "It is amazing what you can accomplish if you do not care who gets the credit".
Congratulations to all three teams and continued success.

speakeroldname: Mr. Peter Milliken (Kingston and the Islands):
speechtext:
Mr. Speaker, all over the world men and women who love freedom will rejoice at the result of the referendum in South Africa yesterday.
State President F. W. de Klerk, his Nationalist Party and his allies in the Democratic Party have achieved a result that gives him a free hand to continue the nation building work that he and the majority of other political parties in South Africa have been engaged in for the last several months.
Canadians have urged this course of action on South Africa for many years as have countless other countries around the globe. Freedom is the only solution to lasting peace in South Africa. The CODESA talks represent a significant movement toward freedom for all of South Africa's races and an opportunity for the state president

March 18, 1992
S. ft 31
and his political colleagues to build a new, stronger and better country.
King George VI said here in Ottawa over 50 years ago: "Without peace there can be no enduring freedom, and without freedom no enduring peace". These words ring true for South Africa today and the referendum represents a giant step toward freedom for the majority of its citizens.

Mr. Speaker, the results of Tbesday's referendum in South Africa show resounding support for President de Klerk and other moderate leaders for the process of reform which has been initiated to end apartheid.
Having just returned from South Africa, I have seen firsthand the significant changes which have taken place in South Africa this past year and feel that the widespread support which President de Klerk's reforms received yesterday should be encouraged and rewarded.
If the aims of achieving a non-racial and democratic South African society are to be successfully reached, we must show support to the government and representative moderate leaders. I commend the Prime Minister of Canada for his prompt telephone call to President de Klerk and the announcement this morning allocating further official development assistance for activities in support of democratic development in South Africa.
Hopefully, as soon as possible the federal government will restore full economic and cultural ties with South Africa, including the establishment of a trade consular office. I encourage Canada to urge other countries to do the same.

Mr. Speaker, yesterday South African whites voted by a substantial majority to give President F. W. de Klerk a mandate to continue on the road to dismantle the evil of apartheid.
We welcome the outcome of this vote and hope that it will in fact accelerate the pace of change in South Africa toward irreversible true democracy and genuine majority rule.
While significant progress has been made it is veiy important however that Canada and other nations of the Commonwealth and elsewhere not lift trade and economic sanctions until there has been irreversible change and the black majority is fully represented at all levels of decision making in South Africa.
Canada must also speak out strongly on the tragic levels of violence in South Africa and call for firm and independent action to end the violence and bring those responsible to justice.
Let this be the last whites only vote in South Africa and let it lead soon to a free and democratic South Africa with an end to poverty, injustice and racism.
Finally, let us pay tribute to Nelson Mandela and the black leadership and the black majority of South Africa for the courage, dignity, and strength they have shown in the struggle to end apartheid.

Mr. Speaker, yesterday the world learned of yet another chilling terrorist attack against Israel.
This time an explosion destroyed the Israeli embassy in Buenos Aires, Argentina. At least 11 people, including children, were killed and more than 100 were injured in this brutal and senseless attack.
Israeli Prime Minister Shamir said the blast was part of a war against Israel.
Our Prime Minister sent the following message to Prime Minister Shamir yesterday: "Canadians were shocked and outraged today at the news of the bombing of the Israeli embassy. We join with civilized people everywhere in condemning this further brutal violence against the state of Israel".
I believe this latest terrorist attack is not only vicious and vile but, worst of all, cowardly.
March 18, 1992

Mr. Speaker, last week the Reform Party was maliciously attacked without provocation for some reason by the NDP member for Churchill as well as other members in this House.
He stated that a Reform Party fundraising letter was a "slick, sophisticated, and sleazy step by step guide on how to abuse the tax system".
I would like to bring to the attention of the House the fact that his own party, the NDP, has also used this method of fundraising so it is not new.
I have in my possession a copy of a document, a B.C. NDP fundraising letter, which reads: "Hans, here is my tax creditable contribution to the grassroots initiative 92.
I am interested in finding out about donating to the B.C. NDP through my will, life insurance or other bequest. Please send me your free pamphlet".
This smacks of hypocrisy unfortunately.
I believe that Canadians are also repulsed by this kind of behaviour and the reaction of Revenue Canada.
Anne, the donor in question, has stated clearly that she did not enter this arrangement with Revenue Canada uninformed. I think what we need to do is say that the official who spoke to her contrary to what we may have heard in this House said there was nothing illegal or wrong about the arrangement-
The hon. member's time has expired.

subtopic: TRIBUTE TO THE LATE ROGER LEMELIN

speakerposition: Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister of Communications
subtopic: TRIBUTE TO THE LATE ROGER LEMELIN
speechtext:
Mr. Speaker, as I watched a few clips from The Plouffe Family yesterday on Radio-Canada, I remembered how families across Canada, literally glued to their TV sets, had become veiy fond of this family from lower town in Quebec City. Roger Lemelin's novel marked the birth of popular television in Canada.
The man who died Monday morning was a gifted author and an outstanding and sensitive communicator. Throughout Roger Lemelin's career, his work gained
him many awards, both in Canada and abroad, particularly from the Academie frangaise and the Academie Goncourt. At 30 he was the youngest member ever elected to the Royal Society of Canada. In 1989 he received the Ordre national du Quebec and finally, two years ago, he became chevalier of the Legion d'honneur.
Roger Lemelin has given us some of our best descriptions of everyday life in Canada.

Mr. Speaker, the member for Beaver River just rose and read part of a mailing from the New Democratic Party of B.C.
Let me assure that member and the House that not only have I read that document, but I also read the entire package. I talked to the Hans in question and there is no way, shape or form that we are asking those people to use the political tax credit to pay premiums.
As I stated in the House on March 11 when I raised this issue, "Canadians will want to know the answer. It is perfectly legal for individuals to give through their wills or through their insurance policies to universities, to political parties and to charities. It is the abuse of the political tax credit that is in question".
I did my homework. We are not guilty. If The Reform Party feels very guilty at death's door, we understand why.

Mr. Speaker, at this time when jobs are at a premium, one of the fastest growing industries in our country has been given a boost.
Recently the minister of western economic diversification announced a project to develop job standards and certification programs for 27 tourism occupations. Now the tourist industry will be more prepared to meet the challenges of tomorrow's international tourism market.

March 18, 1992
Congratulations are due to the minister and everyone involved for their vision and dedication in improving and strengthening our market on the world level.

Mr. Speaker, Saturday, March 21 marks International Day for the Elimination of Racial Discrimination, a day to remind us that ending racism is a long process whose cause all of us must take up daily.
Last night unfortunately we were reminded again that the ultimate act of racism is terrorism with the bombing of the Israeli embassy in Buenos Aires, Argentina, that killed 11 people, injured 120 including many children, smashed windows for blocks and trapped survivors under the rubble.
It is clear the bombing was intended to scuttle the Middle East peace talks or to intimidate the government into closing recently opened files on Nazi war criminals living in South America.
Let us not allow that cruel act to change the course of history. Let us be sure that the meetings continue to move the world toward peace. This incident also reminds us of the ultimate consequences of racism here at home and around the world.
In Canada our fight against racism and hatred go hand in hand with our tradition of tolerance and respect for individual freedom of expression, be it Salman Rushdie's or Mordecai Richler's right to free speech. Racism must be eliminated.

Mr. Speaker, exactly one year ago last Friday, the Prime Minister and President Bush affixed their signatures to the historic Canada-U.S. Air Quality Accord.
With the signing of the accord, both countries took a major step forward in undoing some of the damage we have both inflicted on the environment. We still have a long road to travel before the scourge of acid rain is eliminated from our midst. We must remain vigilant to ensure the terms of the accord are rigorously implemented on both sides of the border.
However, I believe the accord is a classic example of what two great peoples can accomplish when they act in the spirit of goodwill and co-operation.
The many individuals who worked to make the accord a reality, including the Prime Minister and you, Mr. Speaker, are to be commended for their tenacity and diligence in helping to ensure a healthier and cleaner environment for all.

Mr. Speaker, all people in Canada have a basic right to shelter. For the poor, co-op housing has been a saviour, putting a roof over thousands of heads, 5,000 in Winnipeg alone. It allows people shut out of the housing market to have choices and to live in dignity.
In Winnipeg North, a pioneer in co-op housing, there are three such units, but likely there will be no more. The federal government has killed the program though
164.000	families remain on the waiting list and more than
4.000	jobs hang in the balance. This is yet another example of classic Tory betrayal.
Somebody has to provide affordable housing to people in need. Federal responsibilities cannot be unloaded on to the backs of the provinces.
I ask this government: Did you kill co-op housing because it is a social safety net, a Liberal legacy, or because the needs of the poor carry no weight with you? Is it the Tory mandate to let food banks feed them and to let the slums house them?
Bring back co-op housing and address the needs of the poor.

Mr. Speaker, the recently announced export tax on cigarettes of $8 per carton has caused great anxiety and consternation in the tobacco growing communities in and around Tillsonburg and in my riding of Oxford. As a result, the hon. member for Elgin-Norfolk and I have received a petition signed by about 4,500 constituents.
We acknowledge the need to take action to stop the smuggling of cigarettes into Canada, but a way more appropriate than the export tax needs to be found. Not only will this tax seriously injure tobacco producers, but also the support services in those communities, all the way down to those who operate duty free shops at our border crossings.
March 18, 1992

Oral Questions
The Minister of Finance has made it very clear that he is not trying to increase his tax revenue from tobacco sales. It remains for producers, manufacturers, politicians and officials to come up with a more acceptable and effective way to reduce the smuggling of cigarettes into Canada.

speakeroldname: Hon. Jean Chretien (Leader of the Opposition):
speechtext:
Mr. Speaker, I would like to ask the indulgence of the Chair to say a few words on the historic vote in South Africa.
It was a victory for equality of all people, a victory for democracy and a victory for South Africa. On this issue, the House has spoken most of the time with only one voice and I am sure that the Prime Minister will convey on behalf of all members of this House and all Canadians our congratulations and best wishes to President de Klerk and the people of South Africa.
Hear, hear.

Mr. Speaker, coming back to the national scene, I would like to ask a question of the Prime Minister. In the budget papers, the Minister of Finance referred again and again to low interest rates as providing the basis for economic recovery. Since the budget, interest rates have been going up. Yesterday the minister said that it was not his fault; it was the uncertainty over the Constitution.
I want to ask the Prime Minister this question. Does the statement of the Minister of Finance yesterday mean that the budget projections are already wrong?

speakeroldname: Hon. Don Mazankowski (Deputy Prime Minister and Minister of Finance):
speakerposition: Deputy Prime Minister; Minister of Finance; Vice-President
speechtext: No, Mr. Speaker.

speakeroldname: Hon. Jean Chretien (Leader of the Opposition):
speechtext:
Only time will tell, because we have seen the projections of his predecessor wrong all the time, so I wanted to be on the record right away.

The Bank of Canada's policy is merely intent on raising interest rates. This idiotic policy will increase the bankruptcy rate, substantially increase unemployment and poverty in this country and accelerate the deindustrialization of the economy.
Why does the Conservative Government always bow to the Bank of Canada? Who is responsible for this country's economic slump, the government or the Bank of Canada?

Mr. Speaker, with regard to his comment about the former Minister of Finance being out in his projections, in fact, I think the record will show that from time to time he was out by approximately $100 million. However, that is not in the league of my hon. friend who was out by about 100 per cent on a regular basis when his party was in government. Nobody could match the record of my hon. friend and I do not think anybody would ever want to try.

Interestingly, the Leader of the Opposition deplores what he calls a high interest rate policy in the middle of a recession. The minister just explained the reasons for such a modest increase. Interest rates are now at their lowest level in nearly 20 years a major achievement for Canada.
And speaking of raising interest rates during a recession, does the Leader of the Opposition remember the recession in 1981-82, when his government raised interest rates to 22.75 per cent? Perhaps he should think about that for awhile.

speakeroldname: Hon. Jean Chretien (Leader of the Opposition):
speechtext: would remind the Prime Minister that the recession did not occur in 1981-82 but in 1983.
Oh, oh.

Mr. Speaker, I wish to ask a supplementary question.

Oral Questions

Yesterday the Minister of Finance very courageously said that it was not his fault, that it was the fault of somebody else if the interest rates were going up. It was the fault of the Bank of Canada.
This morning the Governor of the Bank of Canada said it was not his fault; it was the fault of the market.
I want to ask the Prime Minister this question. Who is running the economy of Canada? Who is going to take the responsibility for the mess we are in today?

Mr. Speaker, my hon. friend says that the minister indicated that the modest rise in interest rates was the fault of the Bank of Canada. That statement is false.
He then says that the Governor of the Bank of Canada says that the rise in interest rates was the fault of the market. That statement is false.
What can one expect? My hon. friend says that the 1981-82 recession did not take place in 1981-82, that it took place in 1983.

Mr. Speaker, I have a question for the Prime Minister.
Before beginning it, I invite him to look at his own budget papers. They say that the recovery period in 1983 and 1984 was much stronger than the recovery period right now. He should look at his own budget papers.
Yesterday the Minister of Finance tried to blame the current economic mess on constitutional uncertainty, but Canadians know that this recession began long before this current uncertainty. Even the Prime Minister back in 1990 said that his government "had induced a slowdown".
Will the Minister of Finance stop looking for scapegoats for his failed economic policies and look at himself in the mirror and take some steps to reverse his unnecessary return to high interest rates and the unneeded unemployment that goes along with it?

speakeroldname: Hon. Don Mazankowski (Deputy Prime Minister and Minister of Finance):
speakerposition: Deputy Prime Minister; Minister of Finance; Vice-President
speechtext:
Mr. Speaker, yesterday I was responding to the hon. member's questions regarding the recent interest rates.
I said that there was volatility in the financial markets and that it had been caused by a number of factors, including the constitutional issue. I repeat that again. I think that all learned observers would share that view.

Mr. Speaker, my supplementary question is for the Minister of Finance.
The Governor of the Bank of Canada held a press conference and, although invited to do so by journalists, he declined to agree with the Minister of Finance that the current constitutional uncertainty was to blame for the government's return to high interest rates.
Why does the minister insist on an excuse that even his buddy, the Governor of the Bank of Canada, refuses to accept?

speakeroldname: Hon. Don Mazankowski (Deputy Prime Minister and Minister of Finance):
speakerposition: Deputy Prime Minister; Minister of Finance; Vice-President
speechtext:
Mr. Speaker, the hon. member talks about high interest rates.
I remind him that we have the lowest interest rates in 19 years. They are certainly a heck of a lot lower than when the hon. member presided over here on the treasury benches. At that time, five-year mortgages for homes was 19.75 per cent.
The Governor of the Bank of Canada did not deny that the constitutional issue was a factor. As I said yesterday, there are many factors that affect the markets. Whenever there are uncertainties in the markets, it creates a certain amount of volatility, both in the exchange market and in the money markets.

Mr. Speaker, with the same forbearance and indulgence you gave the Leader of the Official Opposition, I have just a few comments on behalf of our party.
I want to say how pleased we are with the outcome of the vote in South Africa, and I want to compliment the Prime Minister for consistently sticking to a matter of principle at the Commonwealth conferences regarding South Africa.
Hear, hear.
And that is that.
Oh, oh.

Back to normal.
March 18, 1992

Mr. Speaker, I want to ask a question about the North American free trade agreement. I was interested in the fact that both the old line parties blamed each other's recession on each other's bureaucrats and any other excuse they could find. Neither one of them spoke about the damage to the economy of this country done by the free trade agreement. None.
I want to ask the Minister for International Trade this question. Considering our experience with the Canada-U.S. Free Trade Agreement, has this government made up-to-date impact studies, sector by sector, of what the draft bracketed agreement will mean to jobs here in Canada, from textiles to automobile parts and automobiles themselves? Has this government done impact studies, sector by sector? If so, will it make them available to the members of this House?

Mr. Speaker, I want to thank my hon. friend for his question, the first part of which is one of the finest he has asked in this House.
I should tell my hon. friend that in a conversation this morning with President de Klerk of South Africa, I conveyed the congratulations of all members of the House of Commons for the excellence of his courageous leadership in bringing this about.
Hear, hear.

As my hon. friend points out, it was on Canada's behalf, with the Commonwealth, a lonely battle from time to time and the government was sustained throughout by the overwhelming majority of the House of Commons. This was a policy that was consistently followed by successive governments over many years and I think it says something about some of the fundamental values of this country of which we can all be proud.
With regard to the less elegant part of the question, my hon. friend asks about the North American free trade negotiations that are presently ongoing. My understanding is that there was the offer of a full briefing for my hon. friend and others tomorrow.
Secret.
No, it is not secret. My hon. friend says it is secret. It is not secret. How could it be secret if we offer to brief the hon. member?

Oh, oh.
Oral Questions

That is an oxymoron, but I invite my hon. friend to come to the briefing. He will find that the Government of Canada will be full and forthcoming in its sharing of information. I look forward to having the opportunity of briefing my hon. friend and then having the House get the benefit of his views thereafter.

Mr. Speaker, if the Prime Minister is making an offer to committee members that they are free to discuss anything they heard in the briefing, I will accept the offer. However, if the conditions remain that we are sworn to confidentiality, when I am sworn to confidentiality, I keep my word. Therefore, I will not go into a secret meeting, sworn to confidentiality.
I asked the Minister for International Trade a specific question about impact studies. My next question is also for the Minister for International Trade. Congresswoman Marcy Kaptur in the United States Congress has made a thorough study of the impact of NAFTA on the United States economy. She has determined that over
100,000	jobs have been lost in the U.S. automobile industry alone, many of them shifting to Mexico. General Motors has recently decided to shift the Moraine Engine Plant to Mexico with a loss to the United States of some 1,000 jobs.
I ask this government whether or not it too has done any specific studies. Has it heard or seen from General Motors that their over-all strategy is quietly to shift its production to Mexico while the negotiations are going on and at the end of the negotiations voila, be almost out of Canada, significantly out of the United States, with the jobs all going to Mexico because of the North American free trade agreement?

speakeroldname: Hon. Michael Wilson (Minister of Industry, Science and Technology and Minister for International TVade):
speakerposition: Minister for International Trade; Minister of Industry, Science and Technology
speechtext:
Mr. Speaker, let me just comment on my hon. friend's point on the access that we have offered members of Parliament with regard to negotiations on the North American free trade agreement.
The committee members, through the committee chairman, came to the government and requested access to the document and the opportunity to have briefings. We, as consistent with the United States and Mexico, have offered confidential briefings to the committee members. It was on that basis that the offer was made.

March 18, 1992
Oral Questions
I believe it is the first time this type of access and involvement in the making of treaties has been offered to opposition members in the House of Commons. My hon. friend-and I believe it is the case with the Liberal Party-has chosen to forgo this opportunity to participate in making policy in order that they can participate in Question Period and in politics of the basest sort. It is that sort of approach that I do not think is becoming of members of Parliament when this unprecedented offer has been made.

Mr. Speaker, the question for the Minister for International Trade is not whether the confidential information is available or not. The question is basically: When is this government going to share with the Canadian people its objectives in the North American free trade negotiations? It is a simple question.
The minister refers to the committee being given information. Many months ago, a year and a half ago, the committee called for the closest possible consultation with Parliament so that the people of Canada had the opportunity to understand what was happening in the negotiations.
Is the minister now saying that the confidentiality rule will not be attempted and, rather, that we will have an open discussion in the committee of the government's policies in this vital issue?

speakeroldname: Hon. Michael Wilson (Minister of Industry, Science and Technology and Minister for International IVade):
speakerposition: Minister for International Trade; Minister of Industry, Science and Technology
speechtext:
Mr. Speaker, I have made known our objectives in the committee hearing about three weeks ago. I have made a number of speeches where I have set out quite clearly what the objectives of the Government of Canada are in the North American free trade negotiations.
What we have offered to both opposition party members of the committee is access to more detailed briefings on a confidential basis so that we can gain the benefit of their judgment on how the process should proceed. It is similar to the process we have under way with the International Trade Advisory Committee and the industry advisory committees where we meet with them on a regular basis, together with the provinces, in seeking
broad sources of advice on the specific elements of the negotiations.
As I have said in my previous answer, this has never been done in the House of Commons. Quite frankly I am disappointed in the hon. member and his colleagues in not allowing this process to proceed in that open way.

Mr. Speaker, what benefit does this bring to the Canadian people? Am I supposed to spend my whole time talking to the member from the New Democratic Party about the deal behind some sort of closed doors?
The question is: What is this government doing to inform the Canadian people? What is it doing about the 50 per cent rule in automotive products? What is it doing on a subsidy code? What is it doing on a dispute settlement mechanism that will be prompt and binding?
These are the questions that we should be having answers to. When is this government going to share with the Canadian people what it is doing in these negotiations?

speakeroldname: Hon. Michael Wilson (Minister of Industry, Science and Technology and Minister for International IVade):
speakerposition: Minister for International Trade; Minister of Industry, Science and Technology
speechtext:
Mr. Speaker, my hon. friend knows that in the previous rounds of multilateral trade negotiations or in the auto pact negotiations his party, the governments that he supported in the past on the Liberal side, gave no information to members of Parliament and gave precious little information to Canadians who were going to be affected by the process.
What we have done on our side when we have been negotiating treaties, the free trade agreement, the North American free trade agreement and the multilateral treaties, is that we have opened up the process.
My hon. friend is very well aware that during the process the government is provided information by industry that is confidential, that is commercially important to other countries if that confidential information is provided. It is on that basis that we have to draw a line. I think my hon. friend is well aware as a member of the private sector before he got to the House of Commons why we must draw that line for commercially confidential reasons.
March 18, 1992

Mr. Speaker, my question is for the same minister. The minister knows Canadian fruit and vegetable farmers already feel that they have been sold out under the Canada-U.S. Free Trade Agreement. These farmers do an incredible job ensuring food security for Canada, and all they want is to be assured by this government that they will be able to continue to provide this food security for all Canadians.
Why does the government refuse to give this guarantee to Canadian farmers?

speakeroldname: Hon. Michael Wilson (Minister of Industry, Science and Technology and Minister for International Trade):
speakerposition: Minister for International Trade; Minister of Industry, Science and Technology
speechtext:
Mr. Speaker, I think the position of the Government of Canada has been extremely forthright and firm as far as the farmers of Canada are concerned.
The positions we have taken in both the multilateral negotiations in Geneva and in the North American free trade negotiations have been developed in concert, in full discussion with the farmers of Canada. It is a position that is supported by the farmers of Canada in both the North American as well as the Uruguay round negotiations.

Mr. Speaker, my question is for the Minister for International Trade.
The government knows that a system of tariffication will not provide the same level of protection for Canadian dairy, egg and poultry farmers as the present system. Yet reports out of the United States say that NAFTA negotiators are discussing a system of tariffication.
How can the government say that it is working against tariffication at the GATT negotiations and at the same time negotiate tariffication at the NAFTA negotiations?

speakeroldname: Hon. Michael Wilson (Minister of Industry, Science and Technology and Minister for International TVade):
speakerposition: Minister for International Trade; Minister of Industry, Science and Technology
speechtext:
Mr. Speaker, the simple fact is we are not negotiating that.
My hon. friend knows-it is an open secret-that a number of countries in the negotiations like to see tariffication without exception. That has been presented. But are we negotiating it with them? No, we are not negotiating it with them.
Oral Questions BREAST IMPLANTS

Mr. Speaker, this past Monday the Minister of National Health and Welfare rose in the House and insisted that breast implants were not available to women in Canada because of the voluntary moratorium. Yet, in the March 9 edition of Maclean's magazine in an article called "Beauty and the Breast", it is reported that an Ontario woman ignored the controversy and had implants the first week in March.
Will the minister investigate and advise the House about this incident as well as how many other incidents of implant surgery have taken place since the moratorium?

speakeroldname: Hon. Benoit Bouchard (Minister of National Health and Welfare):
speakerposition: Minister of National Health and Welfare
speechtext: Mr. Speaker, in the statements I made on breast implants in the last press release, I said that we had asked all concerned, surgeons as well as manufacturers, to refrain not only from using but also from obtaining silicone based breast implants. Of course, if my colleague refers to a specific case which can be investigated to determine exactly what happened, we shall do so and inform her accordingly.

Mr. Speaker, I would assume that was a yes, that the minister will look into this incident and see if there are any other incidents as well.
Yesterday, the plastic surgeons of Quebec held yet another press conference on breast implants and Dr. Roland Charbonneau said that studies have shown women who have breast implants in their body "are getting frightened and it is not justified". He also said that women who want breast implants are "psychologically disabled. They are not happy about their image".
I want to tell the minister that I like my image just fine, and I want to ask the minister if he shares the views of this plastic surgeon that I along with 150,000 Canadian women who are implantees are psychologically disabled?

March 18, 1992
Oral Questions

speakeroldname: Hon. Benoit Bouchard (Minister of National Health and Welfare):
speakerposition: Minister of National Health and Welfare
speechtext:
Mr. Speaker, I do not know why the member asked me that question. She knows very well that what she said was said by somebody else. I never used those words. I always said that the health of women was paramount in terms of how we should deal with that.
I totally agree that there are women who need implants. They need all information available to make their own decision which we must all respect.
In that respect she knows that even if there were requests by the Plastic Surgeons Association in Quebec I did not put out the moratorium. I do not intend to do that as long as the committee agrees.

speakerposition: Deputy Whip of the Liberal Party
speechtext:
Mr. Speaker, today, at the request of this government, GATT is looking into the softwood dispute between Canada and the U.S.
Our softwood industry cannot afford a long, drawn-out process. Does the Minister for International Trade feel that we can get an early resolution through GAIT? When does he expect a decision?

speakeroldname: Hon. Michael Wilson (Minister of Industry, Science and Technology and Minister for International Trade):
speakerposition: Minister for International Trade; Minister of Industry, Science and Technology
speechtext:
Mr. Speaker, there are two processes under way. There is one process, the countervailing duty process, which is under way in the United States. Following that process there could well be the dispute settlement mechanism, the binding decision by a panel on the process in the United States.
The second process is the GATT process to which my hon. friend has referred. We may well see some decisions on the GATT process some time this summer.

Mr. Speaker, my question is for the Minister for International Trade and it concerns the softwood lumber industry.
The government has recently told us on many occasions about the virtues of the bi-national dispute settlement mechanism in the free trade agreement the minister just mentioned. By the time we get a resolution with this process it can take up to two years. In the
meantime the damage would have been done to many of our mills, particularly our smaller mills.
If the government believes that our softwood industry is not being subsidized, what programs and options is it considering? Will it provide interim relief to this industry while the dispute works its way through the process?

speakeroldname: Hon. Michael Wilson (Minister of Industry, Science and Technology and Minister for International Tbade):
speakerposition: Minister for International Trade; Minister of Industry, Science and Technology
speechtext:
Mr. Speaker, my hon. friend is referring to some of the same elements as the previous questioner did.
It is quite right. We have taken action against the United States on the softwood issue, on three different elements of the decision or the action it took. As I indicated, we should see the first indications of those decisions some time this summer; not the two years my hon. friend has referred to.
Let us see what happens with the process as it unfolds. As the member from Winnipeg drew to the attention of the House a week or so ago, certain options are available to us. I think it is important that we complete this process in the strongest possible way and try to win the decisions as quickly as possible.

Mr. Speaker, my question is for the minister answering for agriculture today.
Late last month it was announced that farmers would immediately be able to truck their grain to the United States without off-loading at country elevators and without the regular charges.
This came as a shock to the grain companies. Clearly it was done without consultation. Clearly it was a political directive and clearly it undermined the independence of the Canadian Wheat Board.
What possible explanation does the minister have? Is it one more step toward dismantling the Canadian Wheat Board?

It is in the interest of us all including Canadian farmers to sell as much wheat as possible as quickly as possible.

Mr. Speaker, my supplementary question is for the minister responding for revenue today.
Until recently Canadian farmers trucking grain to the United States were required to fill out what was called the B-13 form for customs officials at the border. I am now advised by customs officials in the province of Manitoba that this practice has been dropped. Mr. Speaker, my question is for the minister of health and welfare regarding the extraordinary assistance plan for thalidomide victims.
I brought three thalidomide victims cases from my riding to the minister's attention in November 1991. All have legal medical proof that their mothers took thalidomide during pregnancy. However, the bureaucrat in his department is stonewalling, refusing to grant hearings, and making unqualified decisions.
As the program expires on March 31, is he going to take his ministerial responsibilities seriously and look over those decisions and ensure that my constituents receive all the benefits they are entitled to?
Oral Questions

speakeroldname: Hon. Benoit Bouchard (Minister of National Health and Welfare):

March 18, 1992

I think it is very important, and I know that the hon. member did it in good conscience when he asked his question, that in these areas we do not speculate, but we base our information on science. I am sure that is what he is interested in and that is what I am interested in.

Mr. Speaker, my question is for the Prime Minister. Our government showed the way by imposing sanctions against South Africa. The overwhelming yes response to the referendum has opened a window of opportunity for new economic relations between our two great peoples. Will the Prime Minister now seize this opportunity to place
trade officials in South Africa so that business, trade and investment in London-Middlesex, and indeed across Canada, may flourish as partners in the rebirth of this great nation before the window is slammed shut?

Mr. Speaker, I thank my hon. friend for an important question. As the House knows, the government, as an indication of the regard that we have for the importance of the decision taken by President De Klerk, committed $5 million today to assist black and white South Africans, particularly black South Africans, to participate economically in development in that area, particularly in regard to the democratic process.
Sanctions that we have followed from the very beginning have been followed jointly with other members of the Commonwealth. The Secretary of State for External Affairs presently chairs the Commonwealth Committee on Sanctions. We met earlier today and agreed that the government will, in co-operation with our Commonwealth partners, seek to send a further signal of confidence to underline the tremendous contribution and leadership shown by President De Klerk at this most critical moment in the evolution of the life of South Africa.
We have always worked together with our Commonwealth allies and we would not want to break ranks now. We will be communicating with members of the Commonwealth to urge them to take some actions now which would send a very positive signal to the President of South Africa and to trading partners around the world and would have the effect of achieving some of the objectives requested by my hon. friend from London a few moments ago.

Mr. Speaker, my question is to the Minister of Finance. The most recent figures show the number of daily car trips by Canadians to the U.S. is continuing to increase. Committees of mayors, reeves and business people in border towns attribute this tendency to the wide discrepancy in the price of gasoline between Canada and the United States.
March 18, 1992

Why will the minister not announce immediately that he is eliminating the 8.5 cents a litre federal tax on gasoline to reduce the number of day trips by Canadians to the U.S.?

speakeroldname: Hon. Jake Epp (Minister of Energy, Mines and Resources):
speakerposition: Minister of Energy, Mines and Resources
speechtext:
Mr. Speaker, I appreciate the hon. member's question which covers a number of different portfolios. May I just say to him that the difference on diesel on the federal excise tax in Canada now is lower than that of the United States. That was done by our government and that should be kept in mind.
Second, we have done a survey of taking the federal excise tax on gasoline, as compared to the American, and we are higher on gasoline, but if you take a look at a comparison as well of a province, say my own province of Manitoba and the neighbouring state of North Dakota and compare those two figures in every province and every state, you will find that if there is room and if there would be any change at all, there would have to be very close provincial co-operation.

I appreciate that answer, but most of the trips that are made in my community are not made by diesel operated vehicles. I think that is a bit of a myth.
In any event, will the minister conduct a study to compare the amount of revenue generated by the federal tax on gasoline as opposed to the cumulative loss caused by cross-border shopping through unemployment, bankruptcies, a lowered municipal tax base and all the other negative effects that one day cross-border shopping trips are having on border towns across this nation?

speechtext:
Mr. Speaker, I was making the case of diesel where, if you look at some of the diesel sales even where we are lower, some of the very arguments that he uses still apply.
I only say to the hon. member that we have used our tax structure, both at the national level and at the provincial level, in a different manner than the Americans have. If there is to be a review, that would be up to our government.
I say to him that there are other factors as well. If you take a look at the over-all tax structure in the United States as compared to Canada, there are for example areas relating to the cost of university fees-I give you
Oral Questions
that-health care fees, or estate taxes which we have eliminated. Those are all differences as well.
One cannot simply look at the one area, though I know he raises it from a very specific perspective. All of those areas have to be looked at as well.

Mr. Speaker, I would like to pose a question to the Secretary of State for External Affairs.
Over the past three weeks we have watched tragically five separate terrorist attacks taking place against Israeli nationals. There were three in Israel itself, one in Turkey and the tragic bombing in Argentine yesterday. The result is over 15 deaths, 125 wounded and many of them schoolchildren, which is something that I think we all abhor.
What action is the Government of Canada taking to protest against these terrorist actions and trying to mobilize international opposition in an effort to stop them while the peace process is gong on?

speakeroldname: Hon. Barbara McDougall (Secretary of State for External Affairs):
speakerposition: Secretary of State for External Affairs
speechtext:
Mr. Speaker, I think this is a point of view that all of us in this House share.
Yesterday the Prime Minister sent the following message to Prime Minister Yitzhak Shamir of Israel: "Canadians were shocked and outraged today at the news of the bombing of the Israeli embassy in Buenos Aires. We join with civilized people everywhere in condemning this further brutal violence against the state of Israel".
There are a number of steps that we are taking. One is our activity in the multilateral round of the Middle East peace talks where we are chairing the working group on the very sensitive issue of refugees.
We have urged all sides to take confidence building measures while these negotiations are going on and to cease acts of violence that lead to the kind of things that we saw yesterday. We do not want to see any repetition on any side at all.

Mr. Speaker, we certainly support sending a letter of condolence to the Prime Minister of Israel.
We are really asking if the Government of Canada is taking action with other countries in the Middle East to ask them to also raise their voice of condemnation especially at a time when the Middle East peace process is so important?

March 18, 1992
Oral Questions
Will the Government of Canada be asking the governments of Egypt, Syria and Jordan to also join the international community in protesting against acts of terrorism so that there can be a total agreement and consensus among all countries in the Middle East that terrorism is not the way to peace?

speakeroldname: Hon. Barbara McDougall (Secretary of State for External Affairs):
speakerposition: Secretary of State for External Affairs
speechtext:
Mr. Speaker, this is a consistent part of our message to all of the countries in the Middle East.
In the multilateral round concerning the peace process that was held in Moscow, I had a first-hand opportunity to speak to many of the countries on both sides of this issue and explain to them Canada's very strongly held views considering terrorism and violence among many of the other things that we talked about, but that certainly is a key part of the message that we portrayed then. We will continue to make it not just in the case of this instance but on a consistent basis.

Mr. Speaker, my question is for the Minister of Energy, Mines and Resources. It focuses on the indications of the Saskatchewan Romanow government that the energy agreement between Canada and Saskatchewan and the nuclear agreement between AECL and Sask Power will be ripped up.
What does the minister see as the potential impact of this premature action by the NDP Government of Saskatchewan? What will it mean for the future of energy for the people of Saskatchewan, including our aboriginal community in my province?

speakeroldname: Hon. Jake Epp (Minister of Energy, Mines and Resources):
speakerposition: Minister of Energy, Mines and Resources
speechtext:
Mr. Speaker, we were very much involved in the agreement that AECL entered into with the Saskatchewan government on behalf of Canada.
With the diversification which I as a member coming from from the prairies know has to take place, we thought we could get diversification in Saskatchewan because it has a world class uranium industry. In fact, it is the single largest private employer in Saskatchewan today.
We also are willing to have an examination. We were not forcing a Candu III on them. We were looking at an ability for them to get the engineering, the research, the technical help and also research, for instance, at the University of Saskatchewan. All those things were included. In fact, we were ready to transfer up to 170 people into Saskatchewan. That has all been stopped by the recent announcement of the premier.

Mr. Speaker, I want to remind the Minister of Veterans Affairs that the merchant mariners of World War II have been asking for justice since 1945 and still do not have it.
Last October the standing committee tabled a unanimous report recommending that merchant navy veterans be recognized as full veterans entitled to all veterans benefits, that an appropriate memorial be erected for merchant seamen and that a Book of Remembrance be placed in the Peace Tower.
The minister's response consisted of a letter to the chairman saying his reply was going to take another month.
When does the minister expect a report from General Smith, his so-called adviser? Will he table his recommendations in this House? When does he expect to report further to the House? Will he do it by making a statement in this House or is he going to continue the callous disregard and indifference to merchant seamen by every government since 1945?

speakeroldname: Hon. Gerald S. Merrithew (Minister of Veterans Affairs):
speechtext:
Mr. Speaker, certainly I and all of my predecessors, and I am sure every parliamentarian here, agree that the merchant mariners underwent some very difficult conditions during the war supplying our troops and so on.
For that very reason, not only this government but previous governments as well, gave them a whole array of programs. There is a misconception out there that they are not getting anything. They get disability pensions, Veterans Independence Programs in some circumstances, civilian war allowance, prisoner of war allowance, campaign medals except the CVSM, atten-
March 18, 1992

dants' allowance, clothing allowance and exceptional incapacity allowance.
I do understand that the merchant mariners want their access criteria widened to other programs the veterans have. In response to that, I might say that this government has undertaken, with veterans groups, the most comprehensive review of this issue since World War II.
I indicated on February 28 that I would have an answer shortly. When the government has a response, we will make a response in the Elouse or elsewhere.
I wish to draw to members' attention the presence in the gallery of His Excellency Dr. Heinz Fischer, President of the National Council of Austria.
Hear, hear.

Mr. Speaker, yesterday in Question Period I put a question, answered by the government House leader, in which I asked him why the government was continuing to index judges' salaries-they are making over $147,000 a year- and freezing other salaries. One hundred thousand PSAC people make less than $25,000 a year.
The minister answered my question by saying he could not answer because there was a bill before the House with respect to judges' salaries.
Ironically, on checking, I found that the bill does not deal with indexing at all. However, that is not the point. The point is that a minister can answer in the House by saying that there is no answer and he cannot give an answer because a bill is before the House.
I made reference to Beauchesne's in which it clearly says that when we are talking about a bill before the House, we are talking about a bill to be debated that day. The Deputy Speaker, Mr. Speaker, in your absence, indicated that she did not know that there had been a ruling in the House that day, a House order, that the
Privilege
debate for the afternoon would be on the environment, not on a judges' bill.
I raise the matter because I am concerned that we might fall into a bad practice in the House. I think this matter needs clearing up because it affects future questions. If a minister can simply stand up and say: "Well I am answering by saying I don't have to answer this question because there is a bill before the House", a pension bill, an environmental bill or whatever, it would seem to me that the government could duck answering a lot of questions. I think this should be cleared up.

I am going to hear further, but I think it is important if there is going to be any discussion on this to understand clearly what the issue is.
The first issue is whether or not the question put by the hon. member yesterday is out of order because it anticipates an Order of the Day. That is the first question.
If it is, then the second matter of whether or not the minister has to answer does not even come into play. Of course a minister does not have to give an answer if the minister does not wish to do so.
But I think the issue we really have to look at here that the hon. member has raised is this: Is the question in order?
The hon. member may want to address the Chair further on that, because that really is the question.

Mr. Speaker, I understood the question was: Is the answer in order? But, of course, a question has to be in order before an answer can be in order.
I would submit the question was in order, in that no Order of the Day was anticipated because the Order of the Day was to discuss an environmental bill. There was before the House sitting on the table a bill on judges' salaries which, of course, did not even deal with indexing, which is what my question was about. But even if it had dealt with indexing-I do not want to stray from the point-my submission is that I could still ask the question because we were not debating that bill.
There are a whole slew of bills before the House and we can still ask general questions on those bills.
The question clearly dealt with what was the government's priority, where it was granting indexing to one group and freezing salaries and not granting indexing to another group?

March 18, 1992
Privilege
I am in perfect agreement with the minister and with the Speaker that the minister could stand up and say he was not answering that question. He has a perfect right to do that. But I submit that he cannot stand up and say that he is answering the question by saying: "I don't have to answer the question because there is a bill sitting there on the table", which may or may not deal with the subject matter, but certainly was not dealing with the subject matter on the day when I put the question.
So the question is in order. I ask the minister to simply stand in the House and indicate that he was wrong. I do not think we should establish a bad precedent like this.

speakeroldname: Hon. Harvie Andre (Minister of State and Leader of the Government in the House of Commons):
speakerposition: Minister of State (Without Portfolio); Leader of the Government in the House of Commons; Progressive Conservative Party House Leader
speechtext:
Mr. Speaker, talk about a tempest in a teapot. The hon. member stood and said this was a point of privilege but I have yet to hear any evidence from him or any suggestions that it is a point of privilege. So I hope you would acknowledge that it is not a point of privilege.
Second, he described his question as a supplementary to the question asked by the hon. member for Vancouver East. 1 think checking into the two questions shows that it was not supplementary in any way, shape or form.
That's not the issue.

speakerposition: Minister of State (Without Portfolio); Leader of the Government in the House of Commons; Progressive Conservative Party House Leader
speechtext: Now he says that is not at issue. Whether his question was supplementary or not is not at issue. He acknowledges that there is no obligation on the part of the government to answer the question anyway, so how can he suggest that an unsatisfactory answer somehow reflects on his privileges, since no answer is a satisfactory answer, or anything else.

I wonder if I could help the hon. government House leader? The hon. government House leader has remarked that this probably is not a question of privilege. It is not a question of privilege; it is a point of order.
But, now that we are into it, I am certainly going to hear it. The hon. government House leader.

speakerposition: Minister of State (Without Portfolio); Leader of the Government in the House of Commons; Progressive Conservative Party House Leader
speechtext:
As I was saying, I think it is a specious point of order anyway.
Perhaps the hon. member will also withdraw his comments where he says "the government has awarded some indexing" and appreciate that in fact the indexing of judges' salaries is a result of an act of Parliament and
not a decision by this government to do anything, not something that can be changed. That is another reason why the question was inaccurate because of its implications or imputations that somehow a decision was made.
I well acknowledge that I was of the opinion that questions, which do occur frequently on here, that deal with legislation that is before the House were out of order. Frankly I think they should be. I think that Question Period should be restricted to what Beau-chesne describes Question Period as, namely an opportunity to seek information from the government that cannot be sought in other ways, such as questions on a bill then before the House. I do not think Question Period should be used for that purpose.
But we can talk about those rules at another occasion.

Just a moment. The hon. member has raised a matter by way of a question of privilege and I have pointed out that it is not a question of privilege, it is a point of order. Surely his colleagues ought to allow the government House leader to respond. The hon. government House leader.

speakerposition: Minister of State (Without Portfolio); Leader of the Government in the House of Commons; Progressive Conservative Party House Leader
speechtext:
As I was saying, I was of the opinion that a question dealing with legislation ought not to be put in Question Period. That is why we have debates. Question Period is not described in Beauchesne and ought not, I believe, be an addition to the debates we have here on legislation.
As to the question of the quality of my answer, all right, I will concede it could have been a higher quality answer. I get back to the comments I made yesterday which the hon. member heard. In fact no answer is required. I was mistaken in suggesting that I did not have to answer. Instead of this answer, please take it out and say my answer is no answer.

Mr. Speaker, perhaps the government House leader, if I understand him correctly, has done what needed to be done, that is acknowledged that the answer he gave in using a procedural argument for not answering when in fact all he had to do was not answer. That is what is at stake here. We acknowledged yesterday that no minister, according to the rules of this House, has to answer a question when it is asked.
March 18, 1992

What we took issue with yesterday was the minister using an interpretation of the rules of the House which was subsequently not validated by the Speaker in order to not answer the question. What we needed either from the Speaker was an instruction that this not happen in the future or an admission by the government House leader that that was not the way he should have dealt with it. I think that is what we just got and perhaps the matter can rest there.
It was certainly never the case that the admissibility of the question was at issue. Whether or not the question was in order was not what was at issue yesterday. Certainly if that had been the case, Madam Speaker would have said something about that. She did not.
What was at issue was whether or not the answer was in order, because it gave what we thought at the time, and still do, and what Madam Speaker appeared to think yesterday, an interpretation to the rules of this House which we felt set a bad precedent. If I understand everything that has been said here today, we agree on that and perhaps the matter does not need to be pursued any further.

speakerposition: Minister of State (Without Portfolio); Leader of the Government in the House of Commons; Progressive Conservative Party House Leader
speechtext:
Except for one thing, the hon. member's question was out of order. It was not a supplementary to the previous question. It was a total distortion.
I will say this about the hon. member for Winnipeg Transcona. I want to congratulate him for not screaming and yelling at the top of his lungs today like he did yesterday.
If the hon. member rises further, I will hear him.

Mr. Speaker, I want to wind up the matter. I see the government House leader has left. I just want to point out very quietly that he is not the Speaker, he is the government House leader and maybe he should remember that.
I want to thank you for hearing me on the point. I accept the government House leader's acknowledgement that he has a different view today than he had yesterday.

I thank the hon. member.

Madam Speaker, I rise today to present a series of petitions signed by over 300 residents of northwestern Ontario, Red Rock, Nipigon, Schreiber, Terrace Bay, Marathon, Heron Bay, Sault Ste. Marie and Thunder Bay.
All of those citizens lost their rail services two years ago. I hope the government is listening.

speakerposition: Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for Science

speechtext:
Madam Speaker, since August 1991, colleagues of mine have been presenting large numbers of petitions in the House dealing with the Nina de Villiers murder in August 1991.
Today I have 24 sheets signed by petitioners who claim that the current criminal law does not require bail hearings in crimes of violence to be presided over by judges and that the risk to society posed by the early release of a violent offender appears to be of secondary consideration to the rights of the individual criminal.
Therefore, your petitioners request that Parliament recognize that crimes of violence against the person are serious and abhorrent to society and amend the Criminal Code of Canada, the Bail Reform Act of 1972 and the Parole Act accordingly.
I humbly present these petitions to Parliament. [Translation]

speechtext:
Madam Speaker, pursuant to Standing Order 36, I have the honour to present a petition signed by electors in Quebec who deplore the fact that for over half a century there has been an illegal trade in Haitian workers between Haiti and the Dominican Republic and that these human beings, who are treated like cattle, are confined within the bateys and obliged to cut sugar cane under conditions that fly in the face of human rights.
Consequently your petitioners humbly pray and call upon Parliament to urge the government to impose diplomatic, political and economic sanctions on the Dominican Republic, until such time as the rights of these Haitian braceros and their families are respected in accordance with the universal declaration of human rights.

speechtext: Madam Speaker, pursuant to Standing Order 36, I have the pleasure to present two petitions from hundreds of residents all across the country, petitioning Parliament to urge the Secretary of State for External Affairs to request the government of Brazil to expel Christine Lamont and David Spencer and return them to Canada.

maintopic: BILL C-61 REPORT OF LEGISLATIVE COMMITTEE C

speechtext:
I have the honour to present two petitions in the name of my constituents.
On the first one, my petitioners indicate that the government is denying equal financial benefits to those who are at home caring for their children as opposed to those who have receipted day care receipts and they want that corrected.
They wanted, as well, that married couples enjoy the same tax benefits and opportunities as common-law couples, but that has changed in the reverse direction in the last budget. They deplore the fact there are many programs that are often confusing and work against the family. They would like to see all of this changed.
March 18, 1992

With regard to the second petition, the people of my riding want the CRTC to regulate foul language on radio and television.
They see often their efforts as parents being eroded and undermined by the language that is often used on radio and television programs. They find that foul language in any language is simply unacceptable. They want the CRTC to enforce strict rules of language conduct on radio and television.

maintopic: BILL C-61 REPORT OF LEGISLATIVE COMMITTEE C

speechtext:
Madam Speaker, I have the honour to present a number of petitions this afternoon.
First of all, I have a petition from residents of Alberta and British Columbia, who point out that two Canadians, Christine Lamont and David Spencer, have been sentenced to 28 years each in a Brazilian prison.
They have suffered miscarriages of justice, cruel and unusual treatment in Brazilian prisons and discrimination in sentencing and parole. The cumulative effect of these irregularities provides ample ground for the government of Canada to seek a remedy on their behalf and that remedy is expulsion.
Therefore, the petitioners call upon Parliament to urge the Secretary of State for External Affairs to request the Government of Brazil to expel Christine Lamont and David Spencer and return them to their homes in Canada.

The House resumed from Wednesday, March 18, consideration of the motion of Mr. Charest that Bill C-13, an act to establish a federal environmental assessment process, be read the third time and passed.

speakerposition: Deputy Speaker and Chair of Committees of the Whole of the House of Commons
speechtext: The hon. member for The Battlefords-Meadow Lake has eight minutes remaining in debate.

Madam Speaker, yesterday afternoon when the time ran out on the debate, I was discussing the matter of policy relating to environmental assessment. At that time, I was talking about the free trade deal with Mexico as being a matter of policy that should be discussed. I will continue that line of debate that began yesterday.
In order to bring in foreign investment and appease International Monetary Fund and World Bank demands, the future of our planet is being, quite simply, sold off at bargain basement prices. Stephen Hasell addressed the committee on behalf of the Canadian Environmental Network. He said: "We think the assessment of the environmental effects of policy and programs should be subject to the over-all legislative framework of Bill C-13".
The essence of our case made by the World Commission on Environment and Development, known as the Brundtland report, can be summarized as follows: human stresses on the planetary ecosystem are now endangering the basic integrity of the system. A good part of
March 18, 1992

the current problem and a worsening concern for the future is the rising numbers and desperation of the world's poor. The living standards of the poor must be raised substantially if population is to be stabilized and environmental abuses resulting from economic desperation are to be eliminated.
Even if the needed economic improvements are achieved quickly, the human population will increase from the current 5 billion to at least 8 billion before stabilizing. The development effort needed to ensure sufficiency and security for all these people is substantial. For many goods, production levels several times higher than current levels are required.
At the same time, development must ensure environmental sustainability or the economic gains will not last.
Finally, development with environmental sustainability can be achieved only if growth is accompanied by strenuous efforts to improve efficiencies and minimize negative impacts, replace environmentally destructive technologies with relatively benign ones, and respect carrying capacities.
The federal government has refused to respect the urgent case made by the World Commission on the Environment and Development. As a result of the fact that current human demands and practices are not sustainable, steps to combat poverty through sustainable development in poor regions and nations must be accompanied by a sizeable over-all reduction of resource use and environmental impact, especially by wealthy nations and regions like Canada. Otherwise, global deterioration will continue.
At the same time it is important to give credit where credit is due. The federal government agreed to include a commitment to sustainable development in the preamble of the bill before us.
The government also agreed to an amendment which significantly expands the definition of environmental effects to include physical and cultural heritage. There was also agreement to include the Brundtland definition of sustainable development as development that meets the needs of the present without compromising the ability of future generations to meet their own needs.
The government also agreed to amendments that would establish public participation at many important steps within the bill. Unfortunately, the legislation itself
Government Orders
does not establish adequate intervener funding, that will be left to the regulations. However, there is no question that room has been made for public involvement in the federal environmental assessment process.
There is also no question that there have been significant improvements to the environmental assessment process itself. With the glaring exception of the screening stage, I was able to win support for amendments which ensure that when a project is to be assessed by a more thorough comprehensive study, a mediation, or an assessment by a review panel the following factors must be taken into account: the purpose of the project, alternative means of carrying out the project that are technically and economically feasible, the environmental effects of any such alternatives, the need for-and this is important-and the requirement of any follow-up program with respect to the project, and the capacity of renewable resources likely to be significantly affected by the project to meet the needs of the present and the future.
The government is to be commended, as is the process during the committee's clause by clause review, for strengthening this important part of the bill.
Another important step the government agreed to in the committee's deliberations was to take into account the impact of any mitigation measures on the decisionmaking process. Also, the government agreed to examine not only the project being assessed but the cumulative impact of the project and other projects on the environment.
For example, if there was a proposal to build a pulp mill which would discharge a certain amount of effluent into a river and also a proposal to reduce the flow of that river for energy purposes the cumulative impact of the effluent on the reduced flow would have to be assessed.
The government also agreed to extend the protection of aboriginal lands in the proposed legislation. The inclusion of several changes, most notably including consideration of lands in which Indians have an interest and aboriginal lands to which claim has been laid, improves the way in which the bill includes these territories in the scope of environmental assessment.
When all is said and done, Bill C-13, an act to provide for a federal environmental assessment process, represents a major step forward. The existing EARP guidelines are tremendously flawed and inefficient. The court cases dealing with Rafferty-Alameda and the Oldman

March 18, 1992
Government Orders
Dam attest to that. As well, the inability to effectively assess projects such as Kemano and Point Aconi further underscore the serious shortcoming of EARP's assessment provision.
When this act was first introduced as Bill C-78 and then reintroduced as Bill C-13 was worse than the existing guidelines. The bill was drafted to please major developers and made it permanent open season on the environment. There is no question that the acceptance by the government of so many of the amendments brought forward during the committee stage went a long, long way toward developing the type of environmental legislation more appropriate to the needs of this country.
The recent acceptance of the concept of the five-year review represents a further step in this long journey toward a delicate and important environmental assessment process.
However let us make no mistake, as I have said earlier there are serious flaws with the bill. It is not the bill we would write if the New Democratic Party were the government in this country. Many of these flaws were consciously put in the bill by members of the cabinet. This government refused to accept attempts to move amendments to further protect Canada's environment by fixing these flaws.
I serve notice to the government and the members of this House that I and my colleagues in the New Democratic Party will work, and work hard, to introduce changes to this legislation in the period during this five-year review to leave Canadians with a better environmental assessment process and, we hope, therefore a better environment for the generations that will come after us.

Madam Speaker, I would like to ask a question of my colleague who just made an eloquent speech. I know that he worked very hard at the committee regarding the report stage of the bill that is now in third reading, and I want to ask him what he thinks of the consideration of this bill. At a time when there is a lot of talk about constitutional issues, at a
time when we wonder, for instance, about the degree of jurisdiction that the provinces should have, at a time when the three main federalist parties all say that they are open to a constitutional renewal, would the hon. member not prefer that this debate take place only in a few months, so as to avoid this whole issue of federal-provincial jurisdictions, and instead give serious thought to what should be a true environmental bill in terms of exclusive federal jurisdiction, and to leave to provinces their own jurisdiction? Like the Canadian Electrical Association says, this bill deals with just about everything but it does not solve the environment problem in a thorough manner.
This legislation will only delay hydroelectric projects and other initiatives that have no impact on the environment. Because of all those delays, and I am talking about delays that are not fixed but that can be extended as much as we want, in the context of the bill this could affect investment planning and those investments might well be made in other countries precisely because our jurisdiction is not clear. We already know that with such a bill, and Minister Paradis from Quebec said so yesterday, we open the door to all kinds of judicial procedures in order to determine which government must intervene: the provincial or the federal.
Does my colleague wish, as a champion of the environment, for this debate to take place in a few months, once we have defined what kind of Constitution we will have in Canada? Are we heading toward sovereignty in Quebec, with two governments having important central powers and with joint economic arrangements? Or are we heading towards a redefinition of Canada, as the three federalist parties hope, with a well defined distribution of powers, for example in the energy sector, like the Beaudoin-Dobbie committee was told? Since this whole debate is not over yet, are we not throwing oil on the fire with such a bill? Are we not thwarting the legitimate aspirations of some provinces like Quebec, which has always wanted better jurisdiction as regards the environment, a full and comprehensive jurisdiction, without constant interference from the federal government to slow down its economic development?
I ask my colleague if he has given some thought to that issue and if he is prepared to share his views with us.
March 18, 1992

Madam Speaker, I am happy to try to answer this question. On numerous occasions in this House I have expressed my belief that the environment is a matter that knows no provincial boundaries, it knows no political or historic boundaries created by humans. The environment extends beyond those artificial boundaries, whether they are created by politics, history, heritage or whatever.
I have always looked at the development of this bill first in terms of the protection of the environment and second, in terms of the way in which the various players in this country would fit into it.
I was not surprised by the remarks of Mr. Paradis that appeared in the media this morning. However, I was a little surprised at the time it has taken for those remarks to come to our attention.
The bill has been with us for over two years. It is a bill that has had considerable attention inside and outside the House of Commons. If I am not mistaken it is a bill that was originally drafted when the member for Lac-Saint-Jean was the Minister of the Environment. It took into account a number of jurisdictional areas.
The bill, as I read it, goes no further on the environment than what was recommended by the Supreme Court of Canada in the Oldman Dam decision. As I recall all judges were of the same opinion on the jurisdictional issues regarding the environment. This bill simply reinforces the Supreme Court decision.
I listened very carefully during committee hearings when the Council of Ministers of the Environment, then represented by the provincial minister of British Columbia, was heard. The Council of the Ministers of the Environment is now headed by the federal Minister of the Environment. At that time there was a fairly strong representation about the ability of the various jurisdictions to work hand in hand.
Although it has some faults, the decision of our committee on the joint review panels very successfully dealt with this area of jurisdiction. While the federal authority is in essence paramount, the joint panels have a significant participation from within the provincial offices. The joint panels, when they are convened, will serve the environment and provincial needs quite well.

Therefore, at least in this part of Bill C-13,1 feel quite comfortable with the direction that has been taken. I feel that the government and the committee have taken the correct steps in this regard.
